questions.question: Don’t forget to signal ……………………. turning right.
questions.description:
It is possible to leave out subject + be after when or while. The above sentence can also be written as:
Don’t forget to signal when you are turning right.

questions.question: I decided to stop and rest ……………………. I was feeling tired.
questions.description: For can be used to give the reason for something. It is more common in a formal style.

questions.question: …………………….. I was feeling hungry, I decided to have lunch.
questions.description: A for clause can never come at the beginning of a sentence.

questions.question: She was acting …………………….. she was the boss.
questions.description: As if and as though mean the same. They are used to say what a situation seems like.

questions.question: You look …………………… you know each other.
questions.description: We use as though to say what a situation seems like.

questions.question: It seems ……………………… it is going to rain.
questions.description: Like is possible here in an informal style.

questions.question: I will remember that experience ………………………… I live.
You can stay in my home …………………….. you do not disturb me.
questions.description: All of these expressions can be used to express a condition.

questions.question: There was a big argument about …………………… we should close the shop.
questions.description: Only whether is possible after prepositions.

questions.question: I am not sure ……………………… I will be able to come.
questions.description: Both whether and if can be used to introduce indirect Yes/No questions.

questions.question: I can’t decide ………………………. to wait or leave.
questions.description: Only whether is possible before a to-infinitive.

questions.question: …………………… I will come I am not sure at the moment.
questions.description: When an indirect question comes at the beginning of the sentence, we use whether.
